note.p: Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.

gloss.p: Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
The criminal act defined as "a sudden, violent attack on someone" or "the crime of attacking and beating someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of stealing from somewhere or someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"A formal written document stating the reasons for bringing a legal action against someone, or the reaction to those reasons given by the defence (or the accused person or their lawyers)." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Religious leaders whose job is serving the needs of their religion and its members; priests, ministers, rabbis, etc." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person whose business is buying and selling goods for profit." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A group of people who have been chosen to listen to the facts in a court action and decide whether a person is guilty or not guilty or whether a claim has been proved." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., a group of people who decide if a person who has been charged with a crime should be given a trial in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: This term refers to the relation, often but not always wives and children, of a person imprisoned in a civilian institution, ranging from jails to penitentiaries.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

Stemming from the first century CE, Christianity is the world's largest religion with over two billion adherents. Its largest denominations are Roman Catholicism, Eastern Orthodoxy, and Protestantism. A large influence on American identity and thought since the nation's founding, Christianity (particularly protestant evangelicalism) spread rapidly in the first three decades of the nineteenth century in the United States due to a series of religious revivals known as the Second Great Awakening. Many Americans injected Christian beliefs and practices into many of the major social, political, and legal debates in the country, including debates over slavery (both pro and antislavery stances), education, and social reform. Christianity also became a prominent religion among the enslaved in the United States, who employed Christian rhetoric and belief in much of their social, religious, and cultural activities, and critical to enslaved people's agency and resistance.

American Christianity in the nineteenth century primarily emphasized both one's individual responsibility to God as well as collective responsibility for one's neighbors. Also deeply important to American Christians in the nineteenth century was millennialism, or the belief that Jesus Christ would establish a 1,000 year reign of peace on earth. These combined elements produced efforts at reform with the intent to perfect society in order to invoke that reign. Many of the enslaved, however, applied millennialism to the hope of slavery's abolition. Numerous politicians also incorporated Christian imagery and language to justify "Manifest Destiny," or the idea that the God of Christianity ordained that the United States' borders would extend from the eastern to western coasts of North America, while both the Confederate and United States governments applied Christian rhetoric to support their causes. Christianity existed and still exists in many different and often competing forms, yet the development of those forms came to define much of American culture in the nineteenth century and beyond (Britannica; Howe, What Hath God Wrought, 285-327; McPherson, Battle Cry of Freedom, 8; Wikipedia).

A Presbyterian is a Protestant Christian identifying with "the Reformed tradition within Protestantism that broke away from the Roman Catholic Church" (Wikipedia). Presbyterians believe in Calvinism, or the teachings of sixteenth century theologian John Calvin (1509-1564). While Calvinism contains many doctrinal elements, the most important separating it from other Protestant Christian denominations is that of predestination, or the idea that God has predetermined who will or will not be allowed into Heaven. Presbyterianism derives its name from a form of church government in which decisions are made by councils of elders (or presbyteries). Presbyterians have a long history in the United States dating back to colonial times, and aside from doctrinal and governmental differences from other Protestant churches, are known for having disproportionate wealth and education, leading to conflicts of race, class, gender, and sexuality throughout the nineteenth century and beyond (Britannica; Wikipedia).

div.p:
To His Excellency Gov. Ames
Governor of The State of Miss.

This will be handed you by Catherine Barrett wife of Henry Barrett who visits you for the purpose of [?] ^asking^ a pardon for her husband. The reason for the pardon is set forth in a petition signed by the best citizens of our county irrespective of party. We have not thought it necessary to present a long list of petitioners; no one has refused, as far as we know to sign the petition, and we doubt not that we could obtain the signature of all persons in this county who are acquainted with the circumstances. We have obtained the signatures of several of the jurors who tried the case and who recommended the party to the mercy of the court—we could obtain the names of all the jurors to the petition if we had the more time to send around to the different parts of the county where they reside. One member of the Grand jury who found the bill told the righter th writer that he thought that a majority of that body would sign the petion if it could be presented to them—Henry Barrett is an industrious and hard working man with a wife and three children dependant on him and their own labor—

for a support—He is high tempered, but not vicious and the offence was committed in day light in front of the Court House as stated in the petition. This is a peculiar case and no conviction could ever have been obtained in such a case except for a defect in our statute—
By the Act of the Legislature of this State approved Oct 30th 1866 Sec. 7. Page 3. justices of the peace in this State have jurisdiction of cases of Pitit larceny in which the amt. alleged to have been stolen does not exceed the value of ten dollars—Under this Statute Henry Barrett was tried by a competent justice of the Peace and for the larceny of the same goods that he has ^now^ been convicted of taking ^robbing^, at the same time that he was tried for the assault and battery; thus he was convicted and suffered the penalty both for the assault and battery of and for the larceny of these same goods, that he is now convicted of taking by robery We interposed the plea that he had once been convicted of the larceny of these same goods and read the law to the court, that when a party has suffered the punishment for larceny he can not again be convicted for the robbery of the same goods, but the Court decided that while this was the law, and that the justice of the Peace had jurisdiction of the larceny in such a case he, had no
jurisdiction of Robery and that we could not therefore plead the same in barr.

Thus by a blunder of the legislature our Client has been compell to suffer twice for the same offence. Again by the law of this State if a man steal ten dollars a magistrate may inflict a small fine, say one dollar and thus the party would make nine dollars clear, but if he receives one dollars worth of stolen goods he must go to the Penitentiary—Your Excellency will find among the signatures ^to the petition^ the names of all the lawyers who are at present in town, together with all our merchants and business men. The Rev. Mr. Steven Archer our Prisbyterian ^minister^ whose name appears also on the list heard the trial, and says that had he been on the jury he would not have found Henry Barrett guilty notwithstanding the tech tecnicality of the law—
Barretts crop is now suffering for want of his attention, and for this reason we have not waited to get more signatures among a population so widely scattered.
Hoping that your Excellency will at once grant the pardon prayed for we remain

F. & L. B. Valliant
